task: Determine the time it would take Eliud Kipchoge, running at his marathon record pace, to cover the distance between the Earth and the Moon at its closest approach, using the minimum perigee value from Wikipedia. Calculate the result in thousands of hours and round it to the nearest 1000 hours.
plan_summary: We will first find the marathon record pace of Eliud Kipchoge, then find the closest distance from Earth to the Moon. After gathering this information, we will calculate the time it would take to cover this distance at the marathon pace.

steps.title: Find Eliud Kipchoge's marathon record pace
steps.details: Search for Eliud Kipchoge's marathon world record pace, focusing on his time for the marathon distance of 42.195 kilometers.

steps.title: Find the minimum perigee of the Moon from Earth
steps.details: Search Wikipedia for the Moon's page and locate the closest approach distance (minimum perigee) from Earth to the Moon.

steps.title: Calculate the marathon pace in km/h
steps.details: Use the marathon record time and distance to calculate Kipchoge's average marathon pace in kilometers per hour (km/h).

steps.title: Calculate time in hours to reach the Moon
steps.details: Using the minimum perigee distance from Earth to the Moon and the calculated marathon pace, compute the total time in hours to cover this distance.

steps.title: Convert the time to thousands of hours
steps.details: Convert the computed time in hours to thousands of hours and round off to the nearest 1000 hours.
